paper_title: STITCH: Simultaneous Thinking and Talking with Chunked Reasoning for Spoken Language Models

sections.title: Abstract
sections.content: Spoken Language Models (SLMs) are designed to take speech inputs and produce spoken responses. However, current SLMs lack the ability to perform an internal, unspoken thinking process before responding. In contrast, humans typically engage in complex mental reasoning internally, enabling them to communicate ideas clearly and concisely. Thus, integrating an unspoken thought process into SLMs is highly desirable. While naively generating a complete chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning before starting to talk can enable thinking for SLMs, this induces additional latency for the speech response, as the CoT reasoning can be arbitrarily long. To solve this issue, we propose Stitch, a novel generation method that alternates between the generation of unspoken reasoning chunks and spoken response chunks. Since the audio duration of a chunk of spoken response is much longer than the time to generate the tokens in a chunk of spoken response, we use the remaining free time to generate the unspoken reasoning tokens. When a chunk of audio is played to the user, the model continues to generate the next unspoken reasoning chunk, achieving simultaneous thinking and talking. Remarkably, Stitch matches the latency of baselines that cannot generate unspoken CoT by design while outperforming those baselines by 15% on math reasoning datasets; Stitch also performs equally well on non-reasoning datasets as those baseline models. Some animations and demonstrations are on the project page: https://d223302.github.io/STITCH.

sections.title: INTRODUCTION
sections.content: Spoken language models (SLMs) can take speech inputs and generate speech outputs (OpenAI, 2024b; Defossez et al., 2024; Arora et al., 2025). SLMs generate speech by emitting some speech tokens, discrete tokens that encode the information in speech (Defossez et al., 2023; Zhang et al., 2024), which will be converted into an audio waveform by speech decoder. Most SLMs are trained from backbone text-based LLM (Defossez et al., 2024; Ding et al., 2025); we can obtain an SLM by teaching the backbone LLM to understand speech input and generate the speech tokens as the output (Xiezhifei, 2024; Fang et al., 2025a). Teaching the backbone LLM to directly generate speech tokens is challenging, as the LLM is originally trained to predict text tokens, so the speech tokens are completely new for the LLM backbone. To make SLMs better predict the speech tokens, current mainstream methods first generate the text tokens before generating the speech tokens (Chen et al., 2024; Zeng et al., 2024; Nguyen et al., 2025). By design, those text tokens and the speech tokens are aligned, in the sense that the text tokens correspond to the semantic content of the speech tokens. While the aligned text-speech generation pipeline makes it easier to generate the speech response, these SLMs directly generate the output text-speech tokens without any inner thinking process, though explicitly modeling such reasoning steps has been shown helpful in text generation tasks (OpenAI, 2024c; Guo et al., 2025). Humans can perform complex internal reasoning before we speak: we disambiguate questions, recall facts, manipulate variables, and then verbalize only the polished answer. Intuitively, this unspoken internal thinking helps improve the accuracy and coherence of our spoken content. However, verbalizing these internal thoughts can make communication confusing and unnecessarily lengthy. Thus, it is desirable to enable SLMs similar ability to think longer and silently before speaking out. naive way to do so is to teach SLMs to generate an unspoken chain-of-thought (CoT) reasoning (Wei et al., 2022) in text, and then generate the spoken responses based on the CoT reasoning. In this way, we can benefit from the CoT reasoning without making the spoken response overly long. While this does improve the speech output quality, as validated by our experiments in Section 5, the speech responses need to wait until the full text CoT is generated, creating an uncontrollable latency for the speech output. To reduce and remove this latency, we propose STITCH: Simultaneous Thinking and Talking with Chunked Reasoning. STITCH alternately generates unspoken reasoning chunks and spoken response chunks, allowing the spoken responses to condition on some thinking process. Since the audio duration of chunk of spoken response is much longer than the time to generate the tokens in chunk of spoken response, we use the remaining free time to generate the unspoken reasoning tokens. When chunk of audio is played to the user, STITCH keeps generating the next unspoken reasoning chunk, achieving simultaneous thinking and talking. STITCH-S, variant of STITCH, has the same latency as the baseline models that cannot generate unspoken reasoning by design, while significantly outperforming those baselines on math reasoning datasets. We summarize our contributions as follows: 1. We propose STITCH, an SLM generation pipeline that outputs unspoken reasoning chunks and spoken response chunks alternately. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to introduce the unspoken thinking process to SLMs. 2. STITCH-S, while improving the generation with unspoken reasoning, has latency the same as an SLM that does not generate text reasoning by design. 3. On five math QA datasets, STITCH consistently outperforms the baseline models that cannot reason with text CoT.

sections.title: 2 RELATED WORK
sections.content: 2.1 SPOKEN LANGUAGE MODELS Our paper improves SLMs by generating text reasoning before generating the speech output. Current SLMs first generate some speech tokens, and the speech tokens will be synthesized into waveform 2 Preprint. Work in progress. by the speech decoder. In this section, we recap how existing SLMs generate speech tokens. The mainstream SLMs nowadays adopt two types of speech generation methods: (1) Interleaved textspeech tokens (Zeng et al., 2024; Li et al., 2025b) and the (2) Thinker-Talker architecture (Xu et al., 2025; Ding et al., 2025; Fang et al., 2025b). In the interleaved decoding paradigm, the SLM backbone model generates chunk of text tokens and chunk of speech tokens alternately. The text tokens serve as guidance for future speech tokens by transcribing what the speech token will say. For example, GLM-4-Voice (Zeng et al., 2024) interleaves between generating Ntext = 13 text tokens and Nspeech = 26 speech tokens. After chunk of speech token is generated, it is immediately synthesized into audio by the speech decoder and streamed to the user, enabling low latency and real-time interaction. figurative illustration of this output format is shown in Figure 2(a). When concatenating the chunk of text tokens, they should correspond to the transcription of the speech tokens. The ratio of the text tokens and speech tokens is carefully selected such that the text tokens are always faster than the speech tokens to ensure that the content of the speech tokens has already appeared in previous text tokens. Once all the text tokens are generated, the model will continue to generate the remaining speech tokens. The thinker-talker SLM uses model, called the thinker, to take speech input and generate text tokens, and uses another model, called the talker, to convert the text tokens and/or their continuous representations into speech tokens (Xu et al., 2025; Ding et al., 2025; Fang et al., 2025b). The talker model functions like Text-to-Speech (TTS) model that converts the textual output from the thinker into speech tokens, and the output by the thinker and talker will be highly aligned in their semantics, while there may be slight differences. The text-speech interleaved SLMs and thinker-talker SLMs differ in their architecture, but they share similarity: they generate text and then the speech, and the text is highly aligned with the speech. In this paper, we focus on enabling SLMs to generate an unspoken thinking process while speaking. 2.2 REASONING FOR AUDIO LLMS AND SLMS While reasoning, also sometimes referred to as thinking, is widely explored in text-only LLMs (OpenAI, 2024c; Wu et al., 2024; Guo et al., 2025; Hong et al., 2025), reasoning is only included in audio LLMs recently. Audio LLMs are multimodal LLMs that can take audio and speech as input, but they cannot generate speech outputs (Changli et al., 2023; Chu et al., 2024; Xu et al., 2025; Lu et al., 2025); this marks significant difference from SLMs studied in our paper. Wen et al. (2025) and Li et al. (2025a) explore using GRPO (Shao et al., 2024) to fine-tune audio LLMs and show that reinforcement learning can improve reasoning ability in audio LLMs on audio question answering. Xie et al. (2025) propose an audio CoT reasoning dataset and fine-tune model to enable the long CoT reasoning ability of audio LLMs. However, no prior work introduces unspoken reasoning ability to SLMs. Only recently, Gemeni-2.5-flash-native-audio (Google, 2025) includes thinking process in the audioin-audio-out mode. After Gemini-2.5 receives the users speech input, it can optionally generate thinking process in text and then give the speech response. However, since the model is black-box, it is unclear how the thinking process is done. Based on our own experience, the model first generate complete text CoT reasoning and starts to generate the speech response, which is different from the simultaneous thinking and talking proposed in our paper.

sections.title: REASONING
sections.content: While current SLMs also include some textual inner monologue (Defossez et al., 2024) or thinking (Xu et al., 2025) (as in thinker-talker) before generating the speech tokens, these text tokens simply transcribe what the model will say next. In other words, they do not generate unspoken reasoning before speaking. In this paper, we aim to improve the SLMs by generating some unspoken text reasoning before generating the speech responses (including the text and speech tokens). Our proposed concept can be applied to both the interleaved and thinker-talker SLMs, but we adopt the interleaved SLMs in this paper for the following two reasons: (1) The interleaved SLM only contains single backbone model to generate the text and speech tokens, simplifying the model 3 Preprint. The arrow represents the timeline for the SLM to generate the tokens; this timeline should not be confused with the timeline that the end user receives the audio, i.e., the upper timeline in Figure 1. We plot tokens of the same type in chunk using the same color. (a) GLM-4-Voice: Interleaving between text and speech token chunks (Section 2.1). This is the design of the original interleaved SLMs. (b) TBS: Generating complete reasoning span and then interleaving between text and speech token chunks (Section 3.1). (c) STITCH-R: Alternating between reasoning token chunks, text token chunks, and speech token chunks (Section 3.2). (d) STITCH-S: Alternating between text token chunks, speech token chunks, and reasoning token chunks (Section 3.3). architecture. (2) Wu et al. (2025) show that the thinker-talker SLM requires careful tuning to make it properly generate well-aligned text and speech output, and the interleaved SLMs do not have this drawback. To unify the wording, we will use reasoning tokens to refer to the unspoken reasoning (in text), text tokens to refer to the original text tokens of the interleaved SLMs, and speech tokens to refer to the speech tokens. Text tokens and speech tokens are the output of interleaved SLMs from prior works (Zeng et al., 2024), and the reasoning tokens are introduced in this paper. Both text tokens and reasoning tokens are texts, while they differ in their function: reasoning tokens are for the unspoken thinking process, and text tokens are the transcriptions of the spoken output. 3.1 TRIVIAL METHOD: THINK BEFORE SPEAKING IN SPEECH (TBS) Before introducing STITCH, we start from trivial baseline method that introduces the thinking process to SLMs: Thinking in text Before Speaking in speech (TBS). Introducing TBS can help us understand the motivation and design of STITCH later. In TBS, given user query in speech, the model first generates complete trace of reasoning span. complete reasoning span is enclosed by two special tokens [SOR] and [EOR], denoting the start and end of the reasoning span. The [EOR] token lets the model know that the reasoning has finished and it needs to start generating the tokens for the spoken response, including the text tokens and the speech tokens. The text tokens and the speech tokens are generated in an interleaved manner, following the original design of interleaved SLMs, with Ntext and Nspeech alternating with each other. To teach SLMs to operate in TBS, we construct the training data DTBS where each training instance has the form (x, z, y), is the speech token sequence of the user input, is the reasoning token sequence, and = [t1 s1 t2 s2, ] is the token sequence for the speech output that interleaves between Ntext text tokens (tj) and Nspeech tokens (sj)1; denotes concatenating two token sequences. We defer how we construct DTBS from existing datasets until Section 4.1. figurative illustration of the target output for TBS is in Figure 2(b). During training, given an input x, we train the SLM to predict the reasoning tokens and then the interleaved text-speech tokens using the standard cross-entropy loss. 3.2 STITCH-R: SIMULTANEOUS THINKING AND TALKING WITH REASONING FIRST While inserting text reasoning before the speech response in TBS improves the quality of the speech response, the speech response can only be generated after the full reasoning has been generated. As later shown in Table 2, the reasoning by TBS can be long, creating significant latency before 1The last text token chunk may be less than Ntext while the last speech token span can have more than Nspeech tokens. 4 Preprint. Work in progress. generating the speech response. To resolve the latency issue, we draw inspiration from the fact that humans can think while speaking and propose STITCH-R. STITCH-R realizes this thinking when speaking by alternating fixed-length (Nreason) partial reasoning spans, fixed-length (Ntext) text token spans, and fixed-length (Nspeech) speech token spans. The partial reasoning spans are for inner thinking, while the text and speech token spans are for the spoken response. Stitching the partial reasoning spans together will form complete CoT reasoning. figurative illustration of the output of STITCH-R is shown in Figure 2(c), and some samples generated by STITCH-R are shown in Table 3. The in STITCH-R stands for reasoning first since it generates partial reasoning chunk before speaking; this is used to distinguish the speaking first STITCH-S that will be introduced in Section 3.3. We explain how simultaneous thinking and speaking is achieved by STITCH-R, which can be most easily understood with Figure 1. After the SLM receives the speech input, it first generates Nreason reasoning tokens, Ntext text tokens, and Nspeech speech tokens for the first audio output chunk S1. Those speech tokens will be passed through the speech decoder to synthesize the audio with duration tchunk seconds and played to the user. When synthesizing the speech waveform and playing the audio for S1, the SLM continues to generate the next Nreason reasoning tokens; this is where simultaneous thinking and speaking happens. After generating the second reasoning chunk, the model continues to generate Ntext text tokens, and Nspeech speech tokens for the next audio chunk S2. As long as the time to generate Nreason + Ntext + Nspeech tokens, denoted as ttoken is less than tchunk, the next audio chunk S2 can be played seaminglessly after the previous audio chunk S1. Lets understand with some concrete numbers. On an A100-80G GPU, our model generate around 80 tokens per second using vLLM (Kwon et al., 2023), and the duration of the audio for Nspeech = 26 speech tokens is around tchunk = 2 seconds, so we can generate around 160 tokens in tchunk = 2 seconds. The number of text tokens and speech tokens sums to Ntext + Nspeech = 13 + 26 = 39, so we have time to generate at most 80 2 39 = 121 reasoning tokens.2 Each partial reasoning chunk is enclosed in two special tokens: [SOPR] (start of partial reasoning) and [EOPR] (end of partial reasoning). If the reasoning chunk is fully generated, an additional [EOR] is used to denote the end of the full reasoning CoT. To construct the training data for STITCH-R, we simply split the full reasoning CoT in DTBS into chunks with Nreason tokens {z1, z2, }, where each zi except the last chunk has Nreason tokens. Next, we interleave those chunks with the interleaved text-speech token sequence = [t1 s1 t2 s2, ] to create the interleaved data of the form [z1 t1 s1 z2 t2 s2 ], as shown in Figure 2(c). If the number of the reasoning span is more than the number of text spans, this indicates that the reasoning token spans think slower than the text token spans, so we remove the sample from the training data.3 The model is fine-tuned to auto-regressively predict the interleaved reasoning-text-speech token spans using standard language modeling cross-entropy loss. 3.3 STITCH-S: SIMULTANEOUS THINKING AND TALKING WITH SPEAKING FIRST STITCH-R can have latency shorter than that of TBS, since STITCH-R only needs to wait at most Nreason tokens before generating the text and speech tokens. However, compared with the original text-speech interleaved SLMs that directly generate the text and speech tokens for the spoken response, STITCH-R still needs to wait for Nreason reasoning tokens. To fully remove the latency for waiting for the first partial reasoning span, we propose an alternative generative pipeline that directly starts to generate the text and speech token chunks and then generates the first reasoning chunk; the model continues to interleave this generation pattern. We call this STITCH-S since it generates speech response first, and an illustrative figure is shown in Figure 2(d). To construct the training data for STITCH-S, we similarly split the full reasoning in DTBS into chunks with Nreason tokens, and insert text token chunk of length Ntext and speech token chunk of length Nspeech before each reasoning span. This can be done by properly selecting the ratio between Ntext and Nspeech. 5 Preprint. Work in progress. STITCH-S looks like [t1 s1 z1 t2 s2 z2 t3 s3, ]. If training instances number of reasoning chunks is more than the number of text chunks, the above data construction pipeline will result in an instance that has reasoning span after the text chunks are finished, which does not make sense since the thinking process hasnt ended while the content to be spoken is finished. We remove this kind of sample from the training dataset.

sections.title: 4.1 TRAINING
sections.content: We fine-tune separate model for TBS, STITCH-R, and STITCH-S from GLM-4-Voice-9B (Zeng et al., 2024). During fine-tuning, we fully fine-tune the backbone transformer model (Vaswani et al., 2017) of GLM-4-Voice and freeze the speech encoder (Zeng et al., 2025) and speech decoder (Du et al., 2024; Kong et al., 2020). Fine-tuning using LlamaFactory (Zheng et al., 2024) takes 17 hours on 32 A100-80GB GPUs. The detailed hyperparameters for fine-tuning are listed in Appendix B. We include three types of tasks in the training data: general dialogue dataset (VoiceAssistant400K (Xiezhifei, 2024)), mathematical reasoning (Tulu-3-Persona Math, Tulu-3-Persona-MathGrade, and Tulu-3-Persona-Algebra (Lambert et al., 2024)), and knowledge-intensive question answering (Natural Question (Kwiatkowski et al., 2019) and TriviaQA (Joshi et al., 2017)). We introduce how to construct DTBS, the training data for TBS, while the training data for STITCH-R and STITCH-S can be constructed from DTBS following the procedures described in Section 3.2 and 3.3. To train TBS, each sample in the dataset needs to have the spoken query x, text reasoning z, and the spoken responses y. For VoiceAssistant400K, which is already speech-to-speech dialogue dataset, we generate the text reasoning using GPT-4o. For mathematical reasoning datasets, which only contain question and its long answer in text, we synthesize the question audio using GPT4o-mini-TTS (OpenAI, 2024a), use the ground truth long answer as the text CoT z, and rewrite the long answer and synthesize its audio to form the spoken response y. For knowledge-intensive QA datasets, which are also in text form, we synthesize the question audio using GPT-4o-mini-TTS, generate the text CoT with GPT-4o, and rewrite the answer and synthesize its audio to form the spoken response y. All the prompts used for constructing the datasets are in Appendix A.1. The full training dataset contains around 400K instances. 4.2 EVALUATION We include both reasoning and non-reasoning datasets for evaluation. We use the reasoning datasets to evaluate whether generating reasoning before responding in speech can improve the spoken answer quality for tasks that require reasoning. We include five math reasoning datasets: AddSub (Hosseini et al., 2014), SinglEq (Koncel-Kedziorski et al., 2015), MultiArith (Roy & Roth, 2015), SVAMP (Patel et al., 2021), and GSM8K (Cobbe et al., 2021), which are commonly used to evaluate the mathematical reasoning ability of LLMs (Wei et al., 2022; Kojima et al., 2022; Wang et al., 2023). The questions and answers in these datasets are not too difficult and can be described clearly in speech, compared to more challenging math datasets like AIME (Balunovic et al., 2025). Since these datasets are originally in textual form, we synthesize the question audio using GPT-4o-mini-TTS. For non-reasoning datasets, we include three knowledge-intensive QA datasets (Llama Questions (Nachmani et al., 2024), TriviaQA (Joshi et al., 2017), and WebQuestions (Berant et al., 2013)) and AlpacaEval (Li et al., 2023), dialogue dataset, from OpenAudioBench (Li et al., 2025b). We use these datasets to understand whether generating unspoken reasoning before responding in speech has any impact on non-reasoning datasets. The statistics of the datasets are in Table 5 in the Appendix. For all reasoning datasets and knowledge-intensive QA datasets, we evaluate the SLMs performance using the accuracy. To calculate the accuracy, we use GPT-4o to judge whether the SLMs prediction matches the ground truth answer. For AlpacaEval, we follow the setting in OpenAudioBench to use LLM-as-a-judge (Chiang & Lee, 2023; Liu et al., 2023; Zheng et al., 2023) to rate the response from 1 to 10, and report the GPT-4o-score scaled to 10 and 100, where higher is better. 6 Preprint. Work in progress. When evaluating the responses from SLMs, we use the text tokens for evaluation. Alternatively, we can synthesize the speech waveform from the speech tokens, transcribe the speech into their transcriptions, and evaluate those transcriptions. However, since the SLMs text tokens are designed to align with the speech output, we only report the performance of the text tokens in the main content. The general trend observed in the following experiment results holds when we evaluate the transcription of the speech output, while the latter has slight performance drop of around 3% to 6%, as shown in Table 6 in the Appendix.

sections.title: 4.3 COMPARED MODELS
sections.content: We compare six models, which are based on the same base model: GLM-4-Voice, an interleaved SLM. GLM-4-Voice has an Ntext = 13 and Nspeech = 26. All the models we use follow the Ntext and Nspeech in GLM-4-Voice. (1) GLM-4-Voice: The model takes speech input and generates interleaved text-speech tokens. This model cannot generate unspoken reasoning by design. (2) No reasoning: We fine-tune GLM-4-Voice on dataset without reasoning, Dno-reason. Each instance in Dno-reason has the form (x, y), which is constructed from DTBS by removing the text reasoning z. The model is trained to predict interleaved text-speech tokens based on the input x. (3) TBS: see Section 3.1. (4) Mix reasoning: We mix half of Dno-reason and half of DTBS to fine-tune GLM-4-Voice. We use system prompt to control whether the model should generate reasoning before generating the interleaved text-speech tokens. This allows us to control the models behavior during inference. By comparing the performance of this model when inference with and without reasoning, we can understand if unspoken reasoning really helps SLMs speech output. (5) STITCH-R: see Section 3.2. (6) STITCH-S: see Section 3.3. During training, we set Nreason = 100 for STITCH-R and STITCH-S. In Section 3.2, we have derived that the length of the reasoning token can be at most 121 tokens when running on an A100-80G GPU, so we select Nreason = 100. We do not compare with other SLMs as they use different training data and have distinct model architectures, making the comparison with our models less meaningful.

sections.title: 5 MAIN RESULTS
sections.content: We present the main results in Table 1. We summarize several key observations as follows: TBS significantly outperforms the baselines without reasoning on math QA. In row 4, TBS achieves an average accuracy of 79.12%, outperforming GLM-4-Voice (row 1) by 26.04% and the no reasoning model (row 2) by 16.14%. The most significant performance gap is GSM8K, which is the most difficult dataset, where the accuracy of TBS almost doubles compared to the two baselines without reasoning. This shows that reasoning before speaking can help the SLM respond better to questions that require reasoning. Reasoning before speaking is better than no reasoning before speaking, even if the training data is the same. The strong result of TBS, compared with the no reasoning baseline may raise question on whether TBS is winning because the training data includes additional reasoning z, which are not included in the training data for the no reasoning baseline. This question can be answered by comparing the results of the mix reasoning model with and without text reasoning before generating the speech response (row 3 vs. row 5). Since the two different inference modes use the same mix reasoning model, the performance difference can be attributed to the reasoning before the spoken response during inference. On average, reasoning before speaking (row 5) obtains an accuracy of 77.47%, outperforming not using reasoning by more than 10% (row 3). For the most difficult GSM8K, the improvement of using reasoning is 24.9%. The results again confirm the importance of generating reasoning before the speech response for reasoning tasks. STITCH-R (row 6) shows almost no performance drop on average. STITCH-R alternates between partial text reasoning and text-speech tokens. While the reasoning is split by text-speech tokens, the average performance only drops by 0.42% compared to TBS. sections.title: 7 USING REASONING FROM OTHER MODELS
sections.content: Previously, we showed that STITCH-R and STITCH-S can generate reasoning before responding in speech. Here, we discuss whether we can improve the quality of the speech response by using the reasoning from other models. The motivation to do this is that sometimes the reasoning generated by the SLM itself is not good enough or takes too long to generate, and we may use other stronger or smaller models to generate the reasoning. We call the model used to generate the reasoning the reasoning augmentation model. We discuss how to improve STITCH-R by using reasoning augmentation model. Given user input speech, we first use an ASR model to transcribe the audio and feed the transcription into the reasoning augmentation model to generate response, which will be used as the reasoning for STITCH-R. Next, we crop the reasoning into chunks of token enclosed by [SOPR] and [EOPR], and then feed the speech input and the first reasoning chunk to STITCH-R and generate the first text-speech interleaved token span. After the first text-speech interleaved tokens are generated, we append the second reasoning chunk to the input and generate the second text-speech interleaved token spans. We continue the above process to generate the full response. In the following experiment, we replace the text reasoning of STITCH-R using four reasoning augmentation models: GLM-4-9B-Chat (GLM et al., 2024), Llama-3.1-8B, Llama-3.2-3B, and Llama-3.2-1B (Grattafiori et al., 2024). We also vary token to see how the length of the reasoning chunk affects the performance. The results are shown in Figure 3c. In general, stronger reasoning augmentation models (GLM-4-9B-Chat and larger Llama models) can improve the accuracy of the spoken response, while weaker reasoning augmentation model like Llama-3.2-1B worsens the performance of STITCH-R. This shows that STITCH-R can incorporate the reasoning ability of stronger models to improve the spoken answer. The experiment also shows that STITCH-R really considers the contents in the reasoning to form the spoken response, instead of independently generating the reasoning and not using that reasoning in the spoken responses.

sections.title: 9 CONCLUSION
sections.content: In this paper, we introduce STITCH, generation framework for SLM that enables simultaneous thinking and speaking. We achieve the simultaneous thinking and speaking by using the long duration of an audio chunk to generate additional reasoning tokens before generating the speech tokens for the next audio chunk. By design, STITCH-S induces no additional latency compared to the models that cannot generate reasoning before they speak. On five math reasoning QA datasets, we show that STITCH-R and STITCH-S significantly improve the accuracy over non-reasoning baselines by over 15%. On non-reasoning datasets, STITCH-R and STITCH-S perform comparably well with non-reasoning baselines. Moreover, we show that STITCH-R and STITCH-S allow flexible control of the length of the partial reasoning span during inference time without retraining the model with an acceptable accuracy trade-off. Last, we find that STITCH can use the reasoning from stronger LLMs to improve the quality of the spoken response. Overall, the low latency and high performance of STITCH show promising future direction for spoken language models.

sections.title: A DATASET
sections.content: A.1 TRAINING DATASET We use three types of training data: dialogue datasets, math reasoning datasets, and knowledgeintensive QA datasets. The sizes of the datasets are in Table 4. We explain how we construct our training datasets from those existing datasets as follows. Dialogue Datasets VoiceAssistant400K (Xiezhifei, 2024) is spoken dialogue dataset built from text dialogue dataset, including OpenAssistant (Kopf et al., 2023) and HH-RLHF (Bai et al., 2022). We subsample the dataset by filtering out (1) the instances whose round attribute is None or 0, (2) the instances from the subset identity, and (3) the instances whose response audio is less than 2 seconds. Given user query and the response or answer from the dataset, we use GPT-4o to generate text reasoning given some in-context samples. GPT-4o is instructed to generate CoTs that understand the users intention, recall relevant information, and provide the final answer. The prompt we use is shown in Table 12. 16 Preprint. Work in progress. Math Reasoning Datasets We include three math reasoning datasets for fine-tuning: Tulu-3Persona Math, Tulu-3-Persona-Math-Grade, and Tulu-3-Persona-Algebra. The datasets include the question and the CoT answer in text. We directly use the ground truth CoT answer as the text reasoning. To obtain the spoken answer, we prompt GPT-4o to rewrite the answer such that the answer is suitable for speech communication and then synthesize it with GPT-4o-mini-TTS. The voice is sampled from the following list: alloy, ash, ballad, coral, echo. The prompt used to rewrite the spoken answer is shown in Table 9. The question audio is also synthesized with GPT-4o-mini-TTS, while the list of voices we sampled from is the same as the previous. The voice of the spoken question and response is selected randomly and independently. The total size of the math reasoning datasets used for fine-tuning is 220K. Knowledge-Intensive Datasets We include two knowledge-intensive QA datasets, Natural Question (NQ) (Kwiatkowski et al., 2019) and TriviaQA (TQA) (Joshi et al., 2017), to preserve the SLMs ability to respond to knowledge-seeking questions. These two datasets are text-based datasets. To obtain the dataset for fine-tuning, we rewrite the ground truth answer from the dataset to make it more suitable for spoken communication, and then synthesize the question and answer audio using GPT-4o-mini-TTS. We sample from the same subset of voices randomly. The text reasoning is also generated by GPT-4o by prompting it with the question and ground truth answer, and asking it to generate an inner monologue that understands the users intention, recalls relevant information, and provides the final answer. The prompts used for rewriting the answer and generating the reasoning are shown in Table 11 and Table 10, respectively. When subsampling from NQ and TQA, we simply take the first 50K instances from NQ and the first 20K instances from TQA without shuffling the dataset before subsampling. The size of knowledge-intensive datasets is around 70K instances. In the original paper that proposes OpenAudioBench, Li et al. (2025b) also use GPT-4o as the judge, and our numbers for GLM-4-Voice are very close to those reported in Li et al. (2025b).

sections.title: D UNSUCCESSFUL ATTEMPTS
sections.content: We detail the unsuccessful attempts and negative findings observed in our experiments. Our aim is to guide future research by highlighting these pitfalls so that others can avoid them. LoRA Fine-tuning Initially, we tried to use LoRA (Hu et al., 2022) for fine-tuning. However, when fine-tuning TBS using LoRA, we found that the resulting model cannot generate useful reasoning. After fine-tuning, the performance on GSM8K is still around 35%, which is almost the same as the accuracy of GLM-4-Voice. By observing the outputs from the fine-tuned model, we observed that the model can generate outputs that satisfy the output format in the training data, i.e., reasoning and then interleaved text-speech tokens. However, the reasoning is seldom correct and can make very trivial mistakes. We suspect that this is because teaching GLM-4-Voice mathematical reasoning requires significant model parameter updates, making LoRA fine-tuning bad choice. Fine-tuning only on Math Datasets We have tried to fine-tune only on the math datasets to teach the model reasoning. However, we found that the resulting model will treat every input query as math question and list some equations to solve the question, even if the question simply asks Which city is located at the intersection of the Tigris and Euphrates rivers? This is possibly because the model overfits to the pattern in the training data and forgets how to solve other non-math questions. However, this can be easily solved by including diverse types of tasks in the training data, which is what we do in the end. Customized Attention Mask When training the STITCH-R model, we tried with variant with customized attention masks. Precisely, we make the reasoning tokens unable to attend to the text tokens and speech tokens, while the text and speech tokens can attend to all types of tokens. The attention mask still remains causal. The rationale for this customized attention mask is to make the reasoning tokens feel like there is no gap between two chunks of reasoning tokens, since they cannot see the text and speech tokens that separate two chunks of reasoning tokens. We use the customized attention mask during training and inference. However, we found that the results on the math reasoning datasets are similar to the results of not using customized attention mask. Considering that the customized attention mask requires some customization during training, complicates the inference procedure, and does not improve the performance, we do not recommend this configuration. 19 Preprint.
